Way too tangential. Just say what happened.

There were reasons called competing interests and the rise of nationalism. Things had been smoldering in Europe for quite a while (a General European war had been narrowly averted in 1905). The assassination, which anecdotally I have confirmed to be the work of the Serbian head of intelligence at the time, Dragutin Dimitrijević, also known as The Apis (The Bee), having spoken with a few Serbians who were impressed I not only heard of this person but even came close to correctly pronouncing his name. He pretty much did what he wanted and no one in the Serbian government wanted to cross him. The assassination was a culmination point that caused things to spiral out of control. When I explained to my wife how Serbia killed the heir to the throne who wanted to make the Slavs co-equal to the Austrians and Hungarians in order to preserve the empire, which is why the Slavs liked him, and the Slavs in the Empire didn’t buy into the Pan-Slavism because they knew it really meant Russian domination and not self-determination. The Archduke actually was offering that, in a way. So when Serbia killed the heir to the throne, the Empire decided to make a list of demands so ridiculous that they would be rejected and the Empire would have its excuse for a war. However, Russia had guaranteed Serbia’s security, which meant war between the Empire and Russia. This meant Germany would have to come to the aid of the Empire because of an alliance and the guarantee, meaning war between Germany and Russia as well. This meant also war between France and Germany because of an alliance between France and Germany and France had actually been moving things along for a war so it could regain Alsace-Lorraine,. This meant Germany had to violate Belgium’s territorial integrity in order to invade France, which meant the UK had to declare war on Germany because the UK guaranteed Belgium’s security. When she heard all of this, she simply said, “How stupid they all were.”

If you are here to actually learn history (not just ace an exam), I recommend researching the Berlin-Baghdad railway. I believe this is the real cause of WW1.

Germany was industrializing and had made agreements with the Ottomans to build a railroad to Baghdad when oil was becoming very important for transportation and production. This threatened Britain's dominance of the sea with the British East India company and its sea routes to India and China. It would have restored the ancient silk road but with the industrial speed of trains which could bring back oil to Germany as well as mobilize German troops to fight the British over access to the Persian Gulf - the world's largest source of oil. Serbia was the last area Germany needed to connect the railroad all the way back.

The motive is there for Britain to have instigated the Franz Ferdinand powder keg.

I don't know if you did not do your research how you should or are you just malicious, but you made several mistakes, which are not that small.

First - Serbs were not defeated at Kosovo Polje in 1389., because Turkish army withdrew from Serbia after the battle. If they won, they would not have flee. Italian and Ragusan merchants wrote about a Serbian victory, also a French cathedral of Notre-Dame rang its bells for 24 hours non stop, after the battle, celebrating the "Christian victory over the Muslim invaders".

Second - Saint Vitus day is not a holiday for "Serbian nationalists" or "Slavic nationalists". Serbs celebrate Saint Vitus day as a Day of Heroes fallen for the Serbian Homeland and the Fatherland. Celebration of Saint Vitus day does not have any kind of nationalistic ring to it, it is something like a Memorial day in USA.

Third - Princip was not a member of a Black Hand, he was a member of Young Bosnia, also, he was not a Serbian nationalist (although a Serb), but a Yugoslav nationalist. His words, on his trial were: "I am a Yugoslav nationalist, aiming for the unification of all Yugoslavs, and I do not care what form of state, but it must be freed from Austria."

Fourth - Black Hand didn't want to create "Greater Serbia", its wishes were to unite Serbia with Bosnia, which had the majority of Serbian population at that time in the history.

Fifth - Ferdinand was not a moderate. He was an antisemite, he also despised Hungarians so much that he wanted, when became an emperor, to shrink Hungarian influence and the territory within the empire, and also planned to use a military force against the Hungarians, if Hungarians disagreed with his view of Empire's internal organization. He wanted a centralized empire with German dominance, with an illusion of decentralization, with a plan to create a third entity within the empire, which would be Southern Slavic or Yugoslav, so empire would be Austro - Hungaro - Yugoslav. All that maybe sounds sweet, but bad thing for the Serbs is that he planned a conquest and annexation of Serbia, into the Empire and again, in full control and dominance of German nation and Vienna.

Sixth - Assassination of Ferdinand was not an act of terrorism, the concept and explanation of terrorism, as we know today, did not exist in 1914. Assassinations of rulers and politicians were very common thing in 19th and, in first half, of the 20th century. You can't put events of 1914. in todays context.

Basically the world back then was always busy with some kind of war... There were wars happening pretty much everywhere long before WW1 and the reason why one of those wars became a thing, was... Technology.

All of a sudden everyone now had guns and artilleries and machine guns and planes and bombs and dreadnaughts... The entire world has suddenly become a much "smaller" place for everyone than it was before, and it really was unavoidable that one day a war would break that could easily affect every single nation around the world. No country was safe from "modern" (for the time) ships and subs and planes and tanks, therefore if you wanted to defend your country, you had to join the war, because like it or not, war was upon you.

Nothing significant started this random war, but new technology was the fuel that made it effective world wide, ultimately making it a world wide war.

1 reason for the war is
Alliances.
If Germany and France hadn't had established an alliance with Austria-Hungary and Italy, and Britain and Russia, the war wouldn't have been a World War, this is the short answer. The long answer is this:
Sometimes, too much allies against too much enemies equals lots of men dying. France and Germany had a logical reason for an alliance, for extra protection, but if there is too much protection, the lives of the protectors will go along with the lives of the country that is protected. In this case if Austria-Hungary declares war on Russia, the members of the alliance will declare war on Germany, which is a logical reason because alliances are alliances, what are they to not declare war on the enemy? They should only declare war if they were invaded without declaration and if the enemy already declares war on the country, in this case, France. Overall, alliances may have protection, but the country that needed them, brought the lives of their protectors with them.

You left out another reason the Archduke's uncle didn't like him. It was something of a scandal that he married Sophie Chotek, a woman pretty much everyone in his family agreed was ill-suited and of too lowly a birth to marry the heir to the Austrian-Hungarian empire. Granted, Sophie was a duchess, so it wasn't like she was some commoner born to working class folks, but still her blood wasn't sufficiently blue enough for the royal family's tastes. Franz Ferdinand was allowed to marry her, but it was a morganatic marriage meaning that he would still be the heir to the empire, but while his wife would be assigned a royal title, Ferdinand couldn't proclaim her as Empress and any children produced in the marriage, were out of the line of secession and couldn't inherit their father's land and titles.

The group that assassinated the Archduke only formed after Austria-Hungary occupied Bosnia, and it had Croat and Muslim members, not only Serbs. I am gonna challenge some points here. First, I would say many knew what was coming, and where more than enthusiastic about it. Most of the powers who participated in the conflict had reasons to want to be at war with each other and where looking foward to it.
First, the british and the german. Long story short, germany wanted his own colonial empire. The UK didnt want to; it was already annoying for them to have to share the "colonial gameboard" with other big players like france, to accept another annoying european competitor in the game. So germany decided to invest lots of money in its navy, in hopes to one day have a navy that could rivalize with the british navy, and as such force the british to stop bothering Germany and letting them have their-so-wanted colonial empire. The first morocan crisis is an example of all of this. So, UK and Germany wanted to go to war to settle this dispute once and for all.
Germany and the austria-hungarians wanted to go to war with russia cause Russia was becoming a serious big deal. Back untill something like 1910, russia was considered a wasteland by europeans. A land of farmers and barbarians, completely drawback and filled of ignorant peasants. But since then, Russia was industrializing... fast. Like, really really fast. And its military was growing with it. In fact, german analist assured the kaiser that by 1918 Russia's military would be more powerfull than Germany. So, the solution: strike them while they are still weak, before they industrialize to that threathening level. Also, there was another issue: the austria hungarian empire was dying. It was inevitable, and german's goveremnt knew it. Going to war with Russia quickly would allow Germany to squeeze just a little bit of military support from the AU before its inevitable collapse.
Russia wanted the war cause he wasnt gonna let AU expand on a slavic territory. Better to attack the AU while it was busy fighting another nation, and weakened, than wait and find out the AU was growing stronger and rebuilding thanks to its military conquest of Serbia!.
Germany and France went to war cause... honestly? it feels like the most chilidish of all the beligerants. They just hated each other, and France wanted Alsace and Lorena back.
And then comes the US, who wants to help France and the UK cause both of them owe the US lots of money and the US is concerned that if they loose in this war, the collapse this defeat would cause on those economies would mean they would never be able to re-pay the US their debts. Also, the US wanted to pretend they had a big groin by participating in such a big deal as the great war was. Japan jumped into the war for more or less the same thing, show they were a big deal. So did the Ottomans, to a degree, altrough it was also in high degree cause of Enver Pasha's stupidity.
Italy went into the war for... reasons. Dunno which reasons where, I bet even the italin high command wasnt sure why they were going to war, but I bet if you dig deep enough you will find some absurd reason.

Here's an interesting alternate take on your alternate take: What if Franz Ferdinand had survived his assassination attempt? He had grand plans for trialism in Austra-Hungary, which would effectively have made the empire a triple monarchy with the south slavs empowered as the Hungarians were. He drew a lot of suspicion in Vienna because of this, in particular in Hungary where the idea was seen as a potential dilution of Magyar power within the empire since the Emperor would have the deciding vote. And in Serbia the idea was regarded by nationalists (and you'd have been hard pressed to find a non-nationalist Serb in 1914 Serbia) as a threat to their dream of a Yugoslavia, and that was one of the driving motives behind the Black Hand's desire to kill Franz-Ferdinand - as a symbol of Habsburg power, but also for what he stood for if he did inherit the crown.

SO F-F survives - does Austria still decide to go after Serbia? What is F-F's moderating influence (if any) on his uncle and the Austrian general staff in the July Crisis? What of Germany's blank cheque, or the other powers' responses, how might they change - the guy did survive, after all. Perhaps it also comes down to how seriously he's wounded - couple of cuts and bruises and he walks away, everybody's pissed but everybody is still alive and well; have him lying in hospital between life and death for a month and he may as well be dead for all the difference it would probably make on the world scene.

So let's say he escapes unscathed enough from Princip's attack that his life is never in danger from his wounds (and I would almost have to go with a foiled attempt, something a bit more drastic than the first car that was bombed earlier that day but not enough to injure Sophie, his wife, in any way. If Sophie had even a scratch on her, I think F-F would have ridden into Belgrade on horseback himself to avenge her - his honour and his devotion to her would have commanded it). Let's go further and say that WWI, though probably inevitable, is averted long enough for Franz-Josef to die and for FF to take the reins of power in Vienna - would his views on Serbia and the greater south slav issue have been very different? A-goes ahead with trialism - how does that dynamic play out both in the Empire and in the Balkan capitals? B-takes on a harder line with the Serbs than before, revigorates the Austrian army and navy in opposition to the growing threat from the south. On one hand this just brings them closer to war; on the other, an A-H Empire run by a younger, more dynamic ruler might have helped to reduce that growing sense of inferiority, of having been overtaken by events, that most Austrians felt at the start of the 20th century, a feeling that the world as they knew it was slowly dying around them, like their 84-year-old emperor. It was that sense of impending doom, of not knowing what to do but knowing they had to do something, that drove the Austrians to war in 1914 as surely as F-F's assassination. Remove that, or revigorate it, with a forward-looking ruler like F-F on the throne... Would history have been much different? Would Germany have felt Austria could handle its own affairs well enough not to need a blank cheque in a later dispute with its neighours? Because Germany, too, felt insecure about Austria's slow but steady decline - many in Berlin felt that it was better to wage a war now (1914) while Austria was still an ally worthy of the name. And in German calculations for the Schlieffen Plan, the Austrians were supposed to absorb the brunt of the Russian onslaught while the Germans knocked out France.
Basically the assassination of Franz Ferdinand was the straw that broke the camel's back.

Here is the real reason. Germany and Austro-Hungary were new empires and therefore lacked colonies to boost their economy. They found the old Ottoman territories on the Balkan to be convenient for serving the purpose, giving them more resources and expanding their influence if they manage to seize them. The assassination was just an excuse, Germany and Austro-Hungary already wanted to conquer Serbia, Bosnia ets.

Bulgaria (which you totally forgot to mention) was already mad at Serbia and Greece for getting only scraps from the division of Macedonia*, which happened between the three of them in the First Balkan War, and the refusal to redivide it which resulted in the Second Balkan War (in which not only Bulgaria failed to get more territory, but also lost some). So Bulgaria also participated in the WW1 on the side of Austro-Hungary in hopes of getting most of Macedonia and some payback.
The territory of Macedonia was the most "ripe" one for grabbing, it was decimated first by by Turkey/Ottoman Empire and then by the Balkan Wars. The Turkish grasp on it was so strong that not only they used upwards of 100 000 soldiers + irregulars in a single city (Krushevo) to suppress the last Macedonian attempt of freedom in 1903, but also a decade later in the First Balkan War they fought against Serbia, Bulgaria and Greece at the same time to try to keep control over it, even though the three themselves were individually able to gain freedom from the Ottoman Empire not too long ago.

*To avoid confusion let me clarify that by Macedonia I am talking about the actual one (all of it), as it was before the First Balkan War, not about the Republic of Macedonia (~32% of Macedonia which was claimed by Serbia, got freed and became part of Yugoslavia and after its fall became an independent republic) or the region in Greece (~51% of Macedonia claimed by Greece in the division, which is confusingly also just called Macedonia).

Although Austria's invasion of Serbia triggered the first world war, it is IMPERIALISM and NATIONALISM fused together that essentially caused this horrific event to happen. Starting from the 1870's, countries were becoming insecure and dependent on imports of raw materials. Only through the acquisition of colonies and search of new markets can this be achieved. Consequently, this led to the rise of conflicts between European powers. Austrian and Russian rivalry for the control of the Balkans is a perfect example that illustrates how imperialism contributed to the formation of a competitive and anarchic international environment. As a result, this prompted the formation of the Alliance system and Militarism which only worsened the building tensions in Europe. This chaotic environment was what allowed for World War 1 to happen. Each crisis in Europe, one by one, increased the chance for war. It was becoming inevitable, and it was only a matter of time. By 1914, countries could no longer refrain themselves and thus initiated the first world war. Not considering the long term causes is ignoring the true causes of the first world war.

1) Gavrilo Princip was not a member of "Black hand".
2) Princip and other assasinators were members of organization called "Young Bosnia" which was not comprised only of Serbs, yet "nationalists", but of Croats, and Bosnian muslims, too. Actually, there were seven assasinators in ambush that day, first of them a muslim guy called Muhamed Mehmedbašić (other six were Bosnian and Montenegrin Serbs, Princip was just the last one of them and the one who succeeded). The genuine idea of uniting all South Slavic people in one country - Yugoslavia (Jug means "south" in Serbo-Croatian language) was fairly present among the youngs of all etnicities and exactly that was the stated goal of "Young Bosnia". Therefore, it could not be by any means a Serbian nationalistic idea, and it cannot be said that archduke was killed by "Serbian nationalist Gavrilo Princip".

Step 1: Forget everything you know

(10) To notify the Imperial and Royal Government without delay of the execution of the measures comprised under the preceding heads.

Historians tell us that the assassination of Franz Ferdinand started the war. That's true but misleading. Imagine a hypothetical situation in the 1980s, fictional, for example, where two diplomats at the UN, one Russian and one American, were sleeping with the same secretary. So one walks in one morning and finds the other in flagrento delecto, and shoots him. This leads to a diplomatic incident which escalates, until one side or the other push the button. Now explaining to the great grand kids in a century or two, that John shot Paul for shagging Alison, and that started WW3, doesn't really make it understandable. You really have to explain the cold war and the Mutually Assured Destruction concept.

Shooting Franz Ferdinand was the trigger, but what caused it was a hundred year old game of Mutually Assured Destruction, where all states had multiple treaties with others, to step in and help if anybody started anything shonky. This ... rat's nest of treaties, arose out of the Napoleonic Wars, where everybody had to work together to stop one man ruling the world.

There is without a doubt western bias present in this video, but i was pleasently surprised how little it affected it. I mean sure, playing with words always causes anger, same as missinterpetations, but i have to notice a few huge gaps here.
One, the reason why Russia was ready to mobilize was not explained very good, it's a bit more complicated than what was presented here.
Second, well mistakes related to Ferdinand being "moderate" and how he would change something if he was alive. Even if we assume that's true, austria had many non-austrians under it's control, and they'd all want their own freedom when the Empire was weak.
Third, the assasination itself. I have to note that i'm very pleasently surprised they payed attention to the date on which Ferdinand came to Sarajevo, which won't be found in almost all western "explanations" of this war.
Fourth, the role of Germany was a bit minimized.

-Yes, Russia was angry that they lost the war with Japan( which was by the way silently supported by GB, and they knew about it about a year before it started ), but they mostly lost the war because they weren't expecting it. They fixed that here, they were ready before everyone else, so victory was assured.
Second, Russia and Serbia had a very, very close partnership especialy at those times. Mobilization was also a way for Russia to warn Austria that they won't sit and watch while they overrun Serbia.  Serbia most certainly shared the cnditions of Austrian ultimatum shortly after they recieved it. Supported by Russia, Serbia rejected one condition which would basicaly deny their sovereginity( and therefore would be unacceptable to everyone ) at the same day Russia started rattling with weapons. That was done at the same time for a reason.

-Ferdinand was seen as a tyrant by the Serbs( i won't use the term "Bosnian Serbs" because the majority were Muslim and Orthodox Christian Serbs, dig into the matter and see for yourself if you dissagree ). Serbian government didn't support destabilization of the region. Serbia just had two balkan wars, it was exausted and didn't need another one, especialy with a country as big as Austria.
Black Hand was an organisation that could have possibly had ties with the "Young Bosnia" movement( which Gavrilo Princip who killed Ferdinand was part of ), but they were just an unofficial organisation that were fighting for unification of all Serbs. Note that i didn't use the term "expansion", because it wasn't expansion, it was liberation.

-There were two assasination attempts on Ferdinand, and the second one was a success. Remember that he was next in line for the Austriah crown. Killing a successor of the throne would usualy spark an internal conflict, especialy in the Austrian empire which had a lot of non-austrians and non-hungarians within it's borders. Black Hand was possibly expecting Austrian empire to fall apart after Ferdinand, as the life of the current Austrian king was nearing it's end.

-Germany had a much bigger role in the war. Not only because it gave a "blank check" to Austria and was the first to declare war to one empire, but also because Vilhem wasn't very skilled. He fired Bismarck, which tried to keep the three big empires ( Germany, Austria and Russia ) on the same side to prevent major wars. Soon after, there was no one to take Bismarck's role and his effort was all for nothing. That was probably the most important factor and a reason why the war went global and why it even started.

Well, Germany encouraged the Austro-Hungarian Empire to declare war and start a swift invasion of Serbia in several occasions. The Austro-Hungarians and Germans were the ones who started the war, not Russia, not France and definitely not Great Britain. Great Britain got caught up in the conflict because it had sworn to uphold Belgium's neutrality.
In fact, there was debate in the British parliament since an important part of British society didn't want to get involved in a "continental conflict". But when Germany invaded Belgium, ignoring its neutrality, Great Britain had to answer, it had to make good on its word, just like Russia had to make good on its promise to defend Serbia.
Germany's move to invade Belgium (in defiance of Britain) was rather shocking, since the Kaiser Wilhelm II was Queen Victoria's grandson, in fact, the Kaiser wanted to avoid a conflict with Britain (his grandma's country) at first, but then he became paranoid, thinking that Britain, Russia and France were planning the invasion of Germany.

PS: It's not surprising that Russia started making preparations for war before any other nation. Russia was (and still is) the largest country in the world. Back then it wasn't even properly industrialized, there was lack of roads, logistics, materials, food, etc. In a country like Russia you had to start making preparations many months ahead, it wasn't like Germany (the most industrialized country back then) or the Austro-Hungarian Empire (with the powerful industry of Czechoslovakia), in Russia things went slow. Also, that was a particularly hard time in Russia. There had been a rather recent revolution attempt in response to decades of tyrannical rule, famine, poverty and backwardness. Most farmers in Russia were starving (and a lot of people in Russia were farmers back then), food production was pretty low. Russian agriculture was agonizing, not only because productivity was low and Russian exports had fallen, but because Russian farmers were put in a pretty untenable position. A lot of Russian landlords had abandoned/sold/mortgaged their lands during the industrial revolution due to low profits/debt, etc. As always, the farmers would have to pay the nasty consequences. The Tsar and his government decided that the farmers would "inherit" the responsibilities of their former landlords. They encouraged farmers to buy those abandoned/mortgaged lands and to pay for those "allotment lands" in redemption dues over decades.
The problem is that those lands were not profitable and weren't sold to individual farmers but to entire farming communities, which then divided those lands among individual farmers.
So whenever individual farmers couldn't make ends meet with their meagre harvests (which was usually the case), they couldn't sell, renounce or mortgage their patches of land, they were basically forced to stay there and starve.
Bottom line, Russia had a deep agricultural crisis that was entering a downward spiral towards total collapse.   
Obviously, a large country with that kind of agricultural problems is bound to collapse, as it happened, finally, in 1917.
Russia was already in deep crisis by 1914, I'm surprised it could mobilize for war at all.

The Russians mobilized to strike against the Austo-Hungarian Empire BUT never actually planned to mobilize just against them. Instead of a partial mobilization they mobilized all of their forces (which were in a pretty poor state), which, of course, upset the German Empire.
But before all that France and Russia hat formed a series of agreements and pacts (Great Britain being involved but never really that interested) which would later (1914) serve as the detonators which would set the powder keg off in the Balkans: Russia was the protector of the Slavic people in the region and allied to Serbia and Russia was intent on getting France to join the war against the Austro-Hungarian Empire and its ally Germany. They knew they'd be fucked if the Germans sent their entire army against them (the most powerful in Europe) against them, so they wanted to involve them in a war on two fronts.

France played a major part setting the stage, partially through their militaristic policies under Raymond Poincaré and rounding up allies for war agains Germany, largely because they feared rising German influence in Africa and Europe as well as Asia and to reclaim territories lost during the war of 1870/1871.

@John Green, you are leaving out a lot of key details in your analysis. Did you forget about the Descos Affair, upon which France pushed the Serbs to have a war with the Austrians so that they would have an excuse to attack Germany if they so wanted. Leon Descos, a French ambassador to the Serbian Kingdom, was dismissed when word leaked out that Poincare's government was discussing Austrian and German plans of war and told them how futile the Hoyos Mission was. Paris was forced to dismiss Descos for his actions and he was replaced by a new minister and Descos was transferred to Romania secretly to discuss a possible alliance there to weaken German resolve. But Germany also pushed for war because Austria would never have declared war without Imperial German backing, which they so chose. And even if France did not get involved the Serbs would never have agreed to Austrian demands for a settlement. The "schoolhouse bullying" diplomacy you mentioned was pulled by German and French diplomats and the Serbs and Austrians never mattered, they were just tools for German and French plans for continental conquest and global power.

Franz Ferdinand was the heir-presumptive to the Austrian Empire, not the heir-apparent. Technically, if his uncle, Emperor Franz Joseph (who was an elderly widower) had managed to produce another legitimate heir after his son, Crown Prince Rudolph, committed suicide in 1889, Franz would have been bumped.  Heir-presumptive means the closest legitimate heir until a closer one is born.  Prince Charles of England is the heir-apparent. In his position as the oldest legitimate child of the reigning monarch, he can't be bumped. Prince Harry was Prince William's heir-presumptive until baby George was born, bumping Harry back in the line of succession.

Much of the reason for Russia's partial mobilisation and period preparatory to war was in response to Austro-Hungarian mobilisation with overwhelming force against Serbija. Russia's western border was guarded by only a few corps in sparse locations. Even though the Russian Army was much larger than the Austro-Hungarian or German Armies, mobilisation would take nearly three times as long to invade either nation than it would for Germany or Austria-Hungary to invade Russia. When Austria-Hungary shows signs of mobilising over 10 corps to defeat the Serbijan 3 corps for invasion, Russia (which supports Serbija) can only assume that such force is a potential measure against itself by Austria-Hungary. The Tsarj fumbles around with partial mobilisation knowing this by means of the Russian intelligence apparatus revamped after the Russo-Japanese War to buy time to move corps from the Kjev and Moskva districts to the west to defend against a possible attack from Austria-Hungary. After Germany states it will aid, Russia can either mobilise to defend itself or it can pull back and cede the Polish and Ukrainian territories to a quick Austro-Hungarian or German offensive. Simply put, Russia was provoked into partial mobilisation by Austria-Hungary and Germany as a means of defending itself, probably so that Germany could fabricate a valid casvs belli against Russia (and France, largely out of the Kaiser's frustration with Germany's poor imperial performance). If anything, Germany is then the primary motivating factor for the War at its World reputation, because Austria-Hungary had no reasonable intention of fighting Russia.

Much of the runnup in Bosnia and Serbia happened due to both Empires trying to retain their Balkan territories. On top of that, the breakdown of the Ottoman Empire is probably one of the most important factors in today's Balkan, Middle East, North African region. Seems pretty important considering not only current events, but many events outside of Europe since 1914.

This misgiving leads us to feel like where when John talks about Eurocentrism as a somewhat negative concept, the leaving out of the Ottomans clearly shows that Crash Course's script writing is indeed a script that is still telling the same story about Europe. long term causes include: imperialism (all the Great Powers wanted 'a slice of the African Cake', and were prepared to slice each other to get it; also increased tension because of imperial nature of Britain, German, France, Russia, etc.)

 the treaty system (everyone dragging their mate in),

the arms race (the great powers all stock piled weapons in the build up; additionally, see the Naval construction race between England and germany, which England owned in terms of amazing productivity),

nationalism (because there can only be ONNNE master race, and everybody thought they were it), and the territory squabbles that lasted 100s of years (see Alsace Lorraine). Also of interest is the years of xenophobic media - eg. in England they would sing famous songs about the evil old Kraut trying to ravish Lady Britannia.

Something that occurred to me a little while back: what the heck would the world population be today if not for the world wars?  Consider these estimates from Wikipedia:
World War I casualties (military + civilian) = 17 million
World War II casualties (military + civilian) = 60+ million

Lets not forget some major causes of death that were pretty much made possible by the world wars (using conservative estimates from Wikipedia):
Spanish Flu epidemic = 50+ million
Deaths attributed to Stalin's purges & policies (non-WW2) = 20+ million
Deaths caused by Mao's Great Leap Forward = 23+ million

That is upwards of 170 million deaths; over 250 million deaths if you use more generous estimates.  Despite all those deaths, the world population went from 1.7 billion in 1900 to 6 billion in 2000.

Why did the Great War happen?
There are three main reasons: alliances, imperialism, and militarism. (Understand these are generalizations.)
European countries made mutual defense agreements with each other. If one country attacked another, their allies would jump in to defend and support the countries. Austria-Hungary attacked Serbia, Russia defended Serbia, Germany declared war on Russia to defend Austria, France declared war on Germany defended Russia, and Belgium and Britain jumped in to France's aid. America would become involved (Canada helped Britain, as they were an extension of Britain, and the United States were eager to defend their European allies and become a greater world power). Peace broke down, and thus war.
Imperialism is increasing wealth, power, and fame by grabbing more territory. Everyone wanted raw materials and land. Competition over land in Africa, Asia, and the Balkans and pride of countries increased confrontation between countries and helped catalyze the war. Imperialism is also what made the Great War a World War. Territories either stayed loyal to their empire (and aided later in the war effort) or split off from their empire.
Militarism was interest in advancing war technology. The arms race was on, with the evil noise of artillery, tanks, and planes booming in the background of the front line infantry. Guns like machine guns, assault/support rifles (the BAR, although usually not classified as an assault weapon, is an example), and submachine guns were also developed. These guns would prove effective in trench warfare.
Then there was the assassination of a certain archduke of Austria that hammered the final nail in the coffin.

Fun Fact: Franz Ferdinand was in favor of turning the Austro-Hungarian Empire into the Austrian Republic, with each Ethnic Group (The Austrian Germans, the Hungarians, the Croatians) within the empire getting equal rights and nearly equal representation. He was also going to ask the Slavic States in the Balkans to join the Republic and also give them equal representation and rights. However, Franz Ferdinand was assassinated, so we cannot know if he would have seriously went through with his reformation plans.

I'm not sure if John will explain it in the next video, but he did leave open why it took a month for the war to begin after Franz Ferdinand's assassination. Yes, getting an assurance from Germany was one reason, but the "Blank Check" meeting between the Habsburg ambassador and the Kaiser happened on July 5. He still left that 20 day gap.

The second reason for the delay was the need to convince the Hungarian prime minister that war was necessary. The Austro-Hungarian Empire was a dual monarchy, with an Austrian government, a Hungarian government, and a small council of ministers (and an emperor) tying the two governments together. The Hungarian prime minister was not a moderate, but he was deeply concerned about the effect of war on his half of the empire, principally from a Romanian invasion of Hungarian Transylvania. So the small council had to convince him that diplomatic overtures were being made to some of the other Balkan countries to prevent that. I think the Habsburg foreign minister also assured Tizsa that Russian intervention was very unlikely. He was convinced by the middle of the month.

The last part of the delay resulted from the Habsburg monarchy deciding to have the ultimatum coincide with the end of a visit by the French president and prime minister to Russia. They wanted to release when they were just about on their way out to prevent to the two leaderships from coordinating a response to the ultimatum. They didn't want their little war interfered with. So they released it on July 25 when Poincare and Viviani were just about to get on the boat back to France (and they would be largely incommunicado for the duration of the trip, allowing the French ambassador in Russia to conduct his own foreign policy which all but assured the Russians that France had their back no matter what and that they should mobilize).

Private Baldrick: The way I see it, these days there's a war on, right? and, ages ago, there wasn't a war on, right? So, there must have been a moment when there not being a war on went away, right? and there being a war on came along. So, what I want to know is: How did we get from the one case of affairs to the other case of affairs?
Captain Blackadder: Do you mean "How did the war start?"
[Baldrick thinks for a moment]
Private Baldrick: Yeah!
Lieutenant George: The war started because of the vile Hun and his villainous empire- building.
Captain Blackadder: George, the British Empire at present covers a quarter of the globe, while the German Empire consists of a small sausage factory in Tanganiki. I hardly think that we can be entirely absolved of blame on the imperialistic front.
Lieutenant George: Oh, no, sir, absolutely not.
[aside, to Baldrick]
Lieutenant George: Mad as a bicycle!
Private Baldrick: I heard that it started when a bloke called Archie Duke shot an ostrich 'cause he was hungry.
Captain Blackadder: I think you mean it started when the Archduke of Austro-Hungary got shot.
Private Baldrick: Nah, there was definitely an ostrich involved, sir.
Captain Blackadder: Well, possibly. But the real reason for the whole thing was that it was too much effort not to have a war.
Lieutenant George: By Gum, this is interesting. I always loved history. The Battle of Hastings, Henry VIII and his six knives, all that.
Captain Blackadder: You see, Baldrick, in order to prevent war in Europe, two superblocs developed: us, the French and the Russians on one side, and the Germans and Austro-Hungary on the other. The idea was to have two vast opposing armies, each acting as the other's deterrent. That way there could never be a war.
Private Baldrick: But, this is a sort of a war, isn't it, sir?
Captain Blackadder: Yes, that's right. You see, there was a tiny flaw in the plan.
Private Baldrick: What was that, sir?
Captain Blackadder: It was bollocks.
Private Baldrick: So the poor old ostrich died for nothing then.

You could have easily said Great Britain and Empire or even just British Empire forces but instead your wording ignores the sacrifices of Australians, Canadians, Gurkha, Indian, Irish, New Zealander, Newfoundlander, South African and any other Dominion, or colonial force that fought with alongside the British army.

Great Britain specifically refers to only the island of Great Britain and its constituent countries of England, Scotland and Wales (though at the time I think Wales was just considered a Principality of England). It is was after all the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, not just Great Britain. Also at this time the Australia, Canada, New Zealand and South Africa were considered Dominions of the Empire, self governing states who signed the Treaty of Versailles independently of the United Kingdom, India was also signed for independently (though the Dominion of Newfoundland did not sign independently), which also meant that the aforementioned dominions and India were also founding members of the League of Nations again as independents as of Part I of the Treaty of Versailles; the Covenant of the League of Nations.

Nationalism and loyalty to squiggles drawn on a globe, resulted in millions of deaths. In a glorified dick-waving competition where major powers tried desperately to cancel each other out. This is the story throughout history, but we never learn. It's similar to watching ant colonies of similar sizes compete and as a result starve oneanother. I'm hoping that as the internet begins to connect every single one of us, we will be more loyal to humanity as a whole than we are to these artificial divisions drawn on the globe, but it's more than just that. There are other unseen lines, lines of ideology, lines of religion, lines of literacy, and it's all just a big goddamn mess. Especially when within the confinds of this border particular ideologies and morals are promoted by the older to the younger generation. I would hazard to say that history is the most important subject, and instead of being taught to simply remember dates and kings, we looked at history to stop it repeating itself.

In which @John Green teaches you about World War I and how it got started. Crash Course doesn't usually talk much about dates, but the way that things unfolded in July and August of 1914 are kind of important to understanding the Great War. You'll learn about Franz Ferdinand, Gavrilo Pincep, the Black Hand, and why the Serbian nationalists wanted to kill the poor Archduke.
